Award.AwardTitle: A Unified Statistical Framework for the Identification of Rare Variants Implicated in Complex Diseases
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is to develop a comprehensive set of statistical methods applicable to high-dimensional and sparse datasets as currently generated by high-throughput genomic experiments. The PI proposes to introduce a novel unified statistical framework to handle large-scale genetic data, and to study its theoretical properties. Within this unified framework, a number of relevant problems can be addressed. The PI will investigate a series of association testing strategies with rare genetic variants that complement and generalize available methods for case-control designs to general designs involving individuals related in an arbitrary fashion. Moreover, the PI will develop an analytic theory to investigate the most powerful statistical designs for association studies with rare variants. The proposed methods will be tested on a broad range of simulated data, and real data from the PIs' collaborators.

The recent progress in genomic technologies has lead to large amounts of genetic data being generated. The emergence of such large-scale, sparse genetic data poses great statistical challenges that require novel and powerful approaches to efficiently extract the information contained in the data. While theoretical, the statistical methods proposed here have the potential to directly contribute to the understanding of the genetic mechanisms underlying complex human traits. To maximize their impact, the proposed methods will be implemented into a software package to be made available to the larger scientific community. Beyond its scientific importance, the project has the potential to contribute to the higher goal of improving the public health. The project also has a strong educational component, and will provide valuable research experience for students and postdoctoral fellows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the major problems in human genetics is understanding the genetic mechanisms underlying complex diseases. Due to tremendous advances in genomic technologies, it has become very efficient to generate large datasets. However challenges in the analysis and interpretation of these data are more difficult to overcome. The main focus of this proposal has been the development of novel testing strategies for identifying rare disease susceptibility variants, using a combination of family-based and population-based designs.

Intellectual Merit. Identifying the underlying genetic causes for common complex traits is a major scientific and public health problem. New advancements in sequencing technologies generate unprecedented amounts of genetic data, and specialized statistical and computational methods are greatly needed to efficiently extract information from these data. As part of this project, we have developed novel statistical methods to test for association with rare variants using both family-based and population-based designs. We have also developed cluster-detection methods to identify genomic regions where disease risk variants cluster more than expected by chance.The methods have been implemented in freely available software packages.

Broader Impact. While theoretical, the statistical methods we have developed have natural applications to the understanding of the genetic mechanisms underlying complex human traits. To maximize their impact, we have implemented the methods  into comprehensive and user-friendly software packages that are freely available to the larger scientific community. The proposal has also had an educational impact.  The PI has mentored two postdoctoral fellows, and several PhD and master level students. Also, the PI has developed a graduate course on statistical methods for high dimensional genomic data, that covers topics such as those discussed in this proposal. This course  is important in training graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in statistical genetics. Finally, beyond its scientific importance, the proposed work has the potential to contribute to the higher goal of improving the public health, by discoverig novel genetic mechanisms underlying risk to autism and schizophrenia.
